body: This is definitely a good idea!!! Let's do this!

issue.title: Pluggable lingual parser

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
This PR adds 
-  `LingualParser` class, which any lingual parser like `Spacy` should inherit from
- `lingual_parser` as an argument to `Parser` to be able to plug a custom lingual parser
Unless otherwise specified, `Spacy` will be used by default for backward-compatibility.

body:
[PyAnnotate](https://github.com/dropbox/pyannotate) looks good. This is a tool that auto-generates PEP-484 annotations.
This has been developed by the same team, at Dropbox, who has originally developed mypy.
Let me try PyAnnotate for a while.

By the way, I don't know exactly what you mean by the following, but I don't think we need a folder 'type' for type hinting. Let me know if I'm mistaken.
> One more question about typing: do you think it's a good idea to have type folder to include all types in Fonduer?

So basically, both MonkeyType and PyAnnotate do the same thing: 1. collect types at runtime and 2. insert collected types to the source code.
I ran `pytest tests` with each but none of the two traced the calls of Fonduer methods because `pytest tests` ran against the Fonduer package installed in site-packages, which is ignored by MonkeyType and PyAnnotate by default.
Fortunately, MonkeyType takes care of such a case by specifying the package to be traced in an environment variable (see [here](https://monkeytype.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq.html#i-run-tests-against-my-package-installed-in-site-packages-and-i-get-no-traces)).

The following works with Fonduer,

1. Collect types
```bash
$ pip install pytest-monkeytype
$ export MONKEYTYPE_TRACE_MODULES=fonduer
$ cd fonduer # move to the root directory
$ py.test --monkeytype-output=./monkeytype.sqlite3
```

2. Insert collected types
```bash
$ cd src
$ mv ../monkeytype.sqlite3 ./
$ # Get a listing of modules annotated by monkeytype
$ monkeytype list-modules
$ # Insert the collected types to a module (e.g., fonduer.parser.parser)
$ monkeytype apply fonduer.parser.parser
```

Great! I think this is definitely a great tool. If I understand it correctly, we can use this tool to auto insert the type and manually correct the wrong ones and add dynamic typing checking using travis test. Does this sound correct?

Yes, you understood it correctly.
It doesn't make any mistake but the coverage is not necessarily perfect depending on the code that runs during the type collection.
The following is one snippet example:
```
     def apply(
-        self, doc_loader, pdf_path=None, clear=True, parallelism=None, progress_bar=True
-    ):
+        self, doc_loader: HTMLDocPreprocessor, pdf_path: None = None, clear: bool = True, parallelism: Optional[int] = None, progress_bar: bool = True
+    ) -> None:
```

`doc_loader` should be typed `DocPreprocessor` instead of `HTMLDocPreprocessor`.
`HTMLDocPreprocessor` has been chosen because the (test) code only uses it.
So yes, we have to manually correct the wrong ones but the tool would do a great job.
Super! Let's do it. This will make Fonduer much easier to use.

issue.title: Type annotations-2 (related to #290)

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
This is another patch related to #290.

Before #295, `mypy src/ | wc -l` (the number of errors) was 681.
At #295, it was 558.
With this patch, it'll be 370.

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
Another series of commits for type annotations (#290).
This reduces the number of mypy complains from 151 to 105.
This PR remains draft until #312 gets merged.

issue.title: Type annotations-7 (related to #290)

repository.name: fonduer
repository.description: A knowledge base construction engine for richly formatted data

issue.body:
This patch
- Enforce mypy check during CI/CD
- Ignore mypy errors for fonduer.learning.* until Emmental gets in
- Annotate types to the rest of all

and this patch finally closes #290.

issue.body:
This is related to #290.

Now that Fonduer has Emmental, it is time to check typing at fonduer.learning.*.
